Other sights are the town hall (16th century) and the ancient mines of the Rammelsberg, which now house a mining museum., 45257=Dr Oliver Junk was elected as Lord Mayor in September 2011., 55207=The alternative theatre Culture Power Station Harz or Kulturkraftwerk Harz is housed in a disused powerstation. textBeforeTable: Climate[edit] Wiedelah Weddingen Vienenburg with Wöltingerode and Wennerode Lochtum Lengde Immenrode Incorporated in 2014: Oker Jerstedt Hahnenklee with Bockswiese Hahndorf with Grauhof Incorporated in 1972: Ohlhof Baßgeige Jürgenohl with Kramerswinkel Sudmerberg Steinberg Georgenberg with Kattenberg Rammelsberg with Siemensviertel and Rosenberg Old Town (upper and lower borough and town centre)      The township currently comprises 18 districts (Stadtteile): Town districts[edit] (clockwise from the North): Liebenburg, Schladen-Werla (Wolfenbüttel District), Osterwieck (Harz District, Saxony-Anhalt), Bad Harzburg, Clausthal-Zellerfeld (Oberharz), and Langelsheim. Neighbouring municipalities[edit] Immediately to the south, the Harz range rise above the historic borough at a height of 636 m (2,087 ft) at Mt. Rammelsberg. Extended forests dominate the landscape. The major rivers crossing the municipal boundaries is the Oker with its Gose/Abzucht and Radau tributaries. The eponymic Gose River originates approximately 9 kilometres (6 miles) south-west of Goslar at the Auerhahn Pass (638 m (2,093 ft)) east of the Bocksberg mountain. textAfterTable: 14 17 18 19 17 15 11 11 13.75 Average daily minimum temperature (°C) 0 0 2 3 5 8 10 10 9 6 4 1 4.8 Mean total rainfall (mm) 110 80 90 60 60 70 70 90 100 120 120 100 1070 History[edit] Main article: History of Goslar Goslar has a rich cultural, political and industrial history. Salian Emperor Henry I founded the town in the 10th century after the discovery of silver deposits in the nearby Rammelsberg. The wealth derived from silver mining brought Goslar the status of an Imperial City, which attracted the interest of the Holy Roman Emperor. The medieval Imperial Palace (Kaiserpfalz Goslar) was built in the 11th century and became a summer residence for the emperors, especially Henry III of Germany who visited his favourite palace about twenty times.
